page.title: List of recurring The Simpsons characters

rev.comment: rv indiscriminate readdition of fair use content
rev.diff:
Line 7: Line 7:
==Akira==
==Akira==
â
[[Image:Akira_The_Simpsons.jpgâ|100px|thumb|left|Akira]]
 
'''Akira''' is a waiter at The Happy Sumo,<ref>{{cite episode |title=One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish|episodelink=One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits=Scovell, Nell; Archer, Wesley M.; Brooks, James L., Groening, Matt, Simon, Sam|network=Fox |airdate=1991-01-24 |season=2 |number=24}}</ref> the teacher of Springfield Martial Arts Academy, and possibly the only recurring [[Japanese people|Japanese]] character in the series.<ref>{{cite episode |title=When Flanders Failed|episodelink=When Flanders Failed |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits=Vitti, John; Reardon, Jim; Brooks, James L., Groening, Matt, Simon, Sam|network=Fox |airdate=1991-10-03 |season=3 |number=38}}</ref> In "[[In Marge We Trust]]" he helped [[Homer Simpson|Homer]], [[Bart Simpson|Bart]], and [[Lisa Simpson]] discover the origin of the mysterious [[List of fictional characters within The Simpsons#Mr. Sparkle|"Mr. Sparkle" box]], Mr. Sparkle bearing a striking resemblance to Homer.<ref>{{cite episode |title=In Marge We Trust|episodelink=In Marge We Trust |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits=Cary, Donick; Moore, Steven Dean; Oakley, Bill, Weinstein, Josh|network=Fox |airdate=1997-04-27 |season=8 |number=175}}</ref> Akira, [[#Luigi Risotto|Luigi]], the [[#The Sea Captain|Sea Captain]], and other Springfield restaurant proprietors planned to assassinate Homer for giving their restaurants bad reviews, but were foiled.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Guess Who's Coming to Criticize Dinner?|episodelink=Guess Who's Coming to Criticize Dinner? |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits= Jean, Al; Kruse, Nancy |network=Fox |airdate=1999-10-24 |season=11 |number=229}}</ref> [[George Takei]] originally voiced Akira in the episode "[[One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish]]". Then [[Hank Azaria]] took over the role, doing an imitation of Takei for the voice.<ref>{{cite video | people=Reiss, Mike; Jean, Al|year=2004|title=The Simpsons season 3 DVD commentary for the episode "[[When Flanders Failed]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref>
'''Akira''' is a waiter at The Happy Sumo,<ref>{{cite episode |title=One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish|episodelink=One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits=Scovell, Nell; Archer, Wesley M.; Brooks, James L., Groening, Matt, Simon, Sam|network=Fox |airdate=1991-01-24 |season=2 |number=24}}</ref> the teacher of Springfield Martial Arts Academy, and possibly the only recurring [[Japanese people|Japanese]] character in the series.<ref>{{cite episode |title=When Flanders Failed|episodelink=When Flanders Failed |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits=Vitti, John; Reardon, Jim; Brooks, James L., Groening, Matt, Simon, Sam|network=Fox |airdate=1991-10-03 |season=3 |number=38}}</ref> In "[[In Marge We Trust]]" he helped [[Homer Simpson|Homer]], [[Bart Simpson|Bart]], and [[Lisa Simpson]] discover the origin of the mysterious [[List of fictional characters within The Simpsons#Mr. Sparkle|"Mr. Sparkle" box]], Mr. Sparkle bearing a striking resemblance to Homer.<ref>{{cite episode |title=In Marge We Trust|episodelink=In Marge We Trust |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits=Cary, Donick; Moore, Steven Dean; Oakley, Bill, Weinstein, Josh|network=Fox |airdate=1997-04-27 |season=8 |number=175}}</ref> Akira, [[#Luigi Risotto|Luigi]], the [[#The Sea Captain|Sea Captain]], and other Springfield restaurant proprietors planned to assassinate Homer for giving their restaurants bad reviews, but were foiled.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Guess Who's Coming to Criticize Dinner?|episodelink=Guess Who's Coming to Criticize Dinner? |series=The Simpsons |serieslink=The Simpsons |credits= Jean, Al; Kruse, Nancy |network=Fox |airdate=1999-10-24 |season=11 |number=229}}</ref> [[George Takei]] originally voiced Akira in the episode "[[One Fish, Two Fish, Blowfish, Blue Fish]]". Then [[Hank Azaria]] took over the role, doing an imitation of Takei for the voice.<ref>{{cite video | people=Reiss, Mike; Jean, Al|year=2004|title=The Simpsons season 3 DVD commentary for the episode "[[When Flanders Failed]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref>
==Artie Ziff==
==Artie Ziff==
â
[[Image:Artie_Ziff.jpgâ|100px|thumb|left|Artie Ziff]]
 
'''Artie Ziff''' ([[Jon Lovitz]], [[Dan Castellaneta]]),<ref>{{cite video|people=Jean, Al|title=The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season DVD Video Collector's Edition commentary for the episode "Homer Defined"|medium=DVD|publisher=Twentieth Century Fox|year=}}</ref> was first seen as [[Marge Simpson]]'s high school prom date with "busy hands" in the first Homer-Marge flashback episode.<ref name="TheWayWeWas">''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode: "[[The Way We Was]]"</ref> He returns in a later episode where he is revealed to have become a nerdy, self-centered and pretentious software billionaire.<ref name="HalfDecent">''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode: "[[Half-Decent Proposal]]"</ref> He offers a million dollars to the Simpsons for one weekend with his childhood love, Marge.<ref name="HalfDecent"/> Ziff returns for the last time in "[[The Ziff Who Came to Dinner]]", where after he gives his bankrupt company to Homer, Homer is taken away by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission as they believed he was the real owner. Ziff later turns himself in (after a romantic encounter with [[Patty and Selma Bouvier#Selma Bouvier|Selma Bouvier]]), where he is extinguishing other prisoners' cigarettes with a spray bottle. Marge told the children to say goodbye to Artie, as they may never see Ziff alive again. He is Jewish; and apparently believes this is why he is so unpopular (when Marge angrily asks if he knows why everyone hates him, he innocently says "Anti-Semitism?".<ref name="HalfDecent"/>) Ziff is based on a man named Mark Eisenberg, who went to high school with [[David Silverman]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1565538/20070725/story.jhtml|title='Simpsons' Trivia, From Swearing Lisa To 'Burns-Sexual' Smithers|accessdate=2007-07-29|date=2007-07-26|author=Larry Carroll|publisher=[[MTV]]}}</ref>
'''Artie Ziff''' ([[Jon Lovitz]], [[Dan Castellaneta]]),<ref>{{cite video|people=Jean, Al|title=The Simpsons: The Complete Third Season DVD Video Collector's Edition commentary for the episode "Homer Defined"|medium=DVD|publisher=Twentieth Century Fox|year=}}</ref> was first seen as [[Marge Simpson]]'s high school prom date with "busy hands" in the first Homer-Marge flashback episode.<ref name="TheWayWeWas">''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode: "[[The Way We Was]]"</ref> He returns in a later episode where he is revealed to have become a nerdy, self-centered and pretentious software billionaire.<ref name="HalfDecent">''[[The Simpsons]]'' episode: "[[Half-Decent Proposal]]"</ref> He offers a million dollars to the Simpsons for one weekend with his childhood love, Marge.<ref name="HalfDecent"/> Ziff returns for the last time in "[[The Ziff Who Came to Dinner]]", where after he gives his bankrupt company to Homer, Homer is taken away by the United States Securities and Exchange Commission as they believed he was the real owner. Ziff later turns himself in (after a romantic encounter with [[Patty and Selma Bouvier#Selma Bouvier|Selma Bouvier]]), where he is extinguishing other prisoners' cigarettes with a spray bottle. Marge told the children to say goodbye to Artie, as they may never see Ziff alive again. He is Jewish; and apparently believes this is why he is so unpopular (when Marge angrily asks if he knows why everyone hates him, he innocently says "Anti-Semitism?".<ref name="HalfDecent"/>) Ziff is based on a man named Mark Eisenberg, who went to high school with [[David Silverman]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mtv.com/movies/news/articles/1565538/20070725/story.jhtml|title='Simpsons' Trivia, From Swearing Lisa To 'Burns-Sexual' Smithers|accessdate=2007-07-29|date=2007-07-26|author=Larry Carroll|publisher=[[MTV]]}}</ref>
Line 91: Line 89:
==Helen Lovejoy==
==Helen Lovejoy==
â
[[Image:Helen Lovejoy.jpg|100px|thumb|right|Helen Lovejoy in her first appearance in "[[Life on the Fast Lane]]"]]
 
'''Helen Lovejoy''', voiced by [[Maggie Roswell]] and [[Marcia Mitzman Gaven]], is [[Reverend Timothy Lovejoy|Rev. Lovejoy]]âs judgmental and [[gossip]]y wife and the mother of [[Bart's Girlfriend|Jessica Lovejoy]].
'''Helen Lovejoy''', voiced by [[Maggie Roswell]] and [[Marcia Mitzman Gaven]], is [[Reverend Timothy Lovejoy|Rev. Lovejoy]]âs judgmental and [[gossip]]y wife and the mother of [[Bart's Girlfriend|Jessica Lovejoy]].
Line 175: Line 172:
==Marvin Monroe==
==Marvin Monroe==
â
[[Image:Dr._Marvin_Monroe.jpgâ|100px|thumb|right|Marvin Monroe]]
 
'''Dr. Marvin Monroe''' is a psychotherapist, who first appears in the first season episode "[[There's No Disgrace Like Home]]". [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] pawns the family television in order to afford a session with Monroe for him and his dysfunctional family. The failed attempt at therapy culminates with the Simpsons [[electroconvulsive therapy|shocking]] each other endlessly, to the point of causing a blackout. Unable to help the Simpsons, Monroe refunds double what the Simpsons paid, and the Simpsons buy a new TV.
'''Dr. Marvin Monroe''' is a psychotherapist, who first appears in the first season episode "[[There's No Disgrace Like Home]]". [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] pawns the family television in order to afford a session with Monroe for him and his dysfunctional family. The failed attempt at therapy culminates with the Simpsons [[electroconvulsive therapy|shocking]] each other endlessly, to the point of causing a blackout. Unable to help the Simpsons, Monroe refunds double what the Simpsons paid, and the Simpsons buy a new TV.
Line 206: Line 202:
==Old Barber==
==Old Barber==
â
[[Image:The_Old_Barber.jpgâ|200px|thumb|right|The Old Barber]]
 
'''The Old Barber'''<ref name="oldbarber"> Groening, Matt. ''The Simpsons Beyond Forever! A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family...Still Continued''. New York: HarperCollins, 2002. </ref> originated on one of [[The Simpsons shorts]], "Bartâs Haircut,"<ref>{{cite video|people=Silverman, David|year=|title=The Simpsons The Complete Third Season DVD commentary for the episode "[[Homer Defined]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref> which aired on ''[[The Tracey Ullman Show]]''. In the short, he cuts Bart's hair too low, and then Bart tries several ways to hide it. [[Dan Castellaneta]] voiced the Old Barber in this short, and based the voice on comedian [[Bob Elliott (comedian)|Bob Elliott]]'s.<ref>{{cite video|people=Castellaneta, Dan|year=|title=The Simpsons The Complete Third Season DVD commentary for the episode "[[Homer Defined]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref>
'''The Old Barber'''<ref name="oldbarber"> Groening, Matt. ''The Simpsons Beyond Forever! A Complete Guide to Our Favorite Family...Still Continued''. New York: HarperCollins, 2002. </ref> originated on one of [[The Simpsons shorts]], "Bartâs Haircut,"<ref>{{cite video|people=Silverman, David|year=|title=The Simpsons The Complete Third Season DVD commentary for the episode "[[Homer Defined]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref> which aired on ''[[The Tracey Ullman Show]]''. In the short, he cuts Bart's hair too low, and then Bart tries several ways to hide it. [[Dan Castellaneta]] voiced the Old Barber in this short, and based the voice on comedian [[Bob Elliott (comedian)|Bob Elliott]]'s.<ref>{{cite video|people=Castellaneta, Dan|year=|title=The Simpsons The Complete Third Season DVD commentary for the episode "[[Homer Defined]]"| medium=DVD||publisher=20th Century Fox}}</ref>
Line 281: Line 276:
==Squeaky Voiced Teen==
==Squeaky Voiced Teen==
â
[[Image:Squeaky-Voiced_Teen.png|50px|thumb|right|Squeaky-Voiced Teen]]
 
'''Squeaky Voiced Teen''', also known as '''Jeremy Freedman''' (voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]), is one of few [[adolescence|teenagers]] on the show and is perpetually trapped in a series of dead-end jobs that do not lead him anywhere, usually working at Krusty Burger (as a cashier) or at a movie theater (as either the ticket master or an usher). He is seen working in many establishments before being fired or quitting. The Squeaky Voiced Teen has [[acne vulgaris]], and his voice is in the process of breaking. The Squeaky Voiced Teen's personality is shy, pathetic, miserable, and awkward. He is often concerned about others and usually reports them to his boss; however, when he very rarely is the boss himself, he seizes opportunity and becomes stubborn and demanding.
'''Squeaky Voiced Teen''', also known as '''Jeremy Freedman''' (voiced by [[Dan Castellaneta]]), is one of few [[adolescence|teenagers]] on the show and is perpetually trapped in a series of dead-end jobs that do not lead him anywhere, usually working at Krusty Burger (as a cashier) or at a movie theater (as either the ticket master or an usher). He is seen working in many establishments before being fired or quitting. The Squeaky Voiced Teen has [[acne vulgaris]], and his voice is in the process of breaking. The Squeaky Voiced Teen's personality is shy, pathetic, miserable, and awkward. He is often concerned about others and usually reports them to his boss; however, when he very rarely is the boss himself, he seizes opportunity and becomes stubborn and demanding.
